alt_statements.statement: I think artificial intelligence should mainly be used to help people, like making doctors better at finding what’s wrong or helping teachers explain things in easier ways. Grown-ups should make strong rules so AI can’t be used to hurt people, lie, or take away jobs without helping families. I believe God wants us to use our inventions kindly and fairly, so we should always check that AI is honest, safe, and used to care for others, not just to make money.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people, like making schoolwork easier to understand, helping doctors, and solving big problems like pollution, but it should never replace real human kindness or fairness. Adults should make strong rules so AI can’t be used to hurt people, spread lies, or treat anyone unfairly because of who they are. I also think regular people, not just big tech companies, should get a say in how AI is used, so it stays something that helps families and communities instead of controlling them.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make people’s lives easier and more dignified—especially in areas like healthcare, disability support, and social services—but it must never replace real human judgment, empathy, or accountability. Given how easily people without money, power, or insurance get overlooked, AI systems must be tightly regulated, transparently tested for bias, and governed by laws that put human rights, privacy, and fairness ahead of corporate profit or government surveillance.

I think AI should be used to make life fairer and easier for regular people, like improving healthcare access, public transportation, and education, not just making rich companies richer. But we’ve got to lock down the risks: strong laws against biased algorithms, surveillance, and job loss without a safety net, plus real transparency about how AI makes decisions. I’d want diverse, everyday folks—especially people of color and workers like me—at the table when these rules are made, not just tech CEOs and politicians.

Creo que la inteligencia artificial puede ser una herramienta útil para hacer el trabajo más eficiente, ayudar en la medicina y mejorar servicios básicos, siempre y cuando no reemplace la dignidad ni el sustento de las personas trabajadoras. Me preocupa que pueda quitar empleos a gente sencilla como yo, o que se use para vigilar o manipular a la población, así que el gobierno y las empresas deben poner reglas claras, responsables y con supervisión humana. Desde mis valores cristianos, pienso que la tecnología debe servir a la persona, proteger a los más vulnerables y respetar la libertad y la privacidad.

AI should be used to make everyday life easier and safer, like improving healthcare, transportation, and education, especially for working families and immigrants who don’t always get the best services. But companies and the government must be transparent about how AI works, protect our jobs and privacy, and make sure it doesn’t discriminate against people because of where they’re from or how they look. We need strong, fair rules, with input from regular people—not just tech CEOs—so that AI serves everyone, not just those already on top.

As someone who works in a hospital and sees both the promise and the limits of technology every day, I think artificial intelligence should be used to support human judgment, not replace it—especially in areas that affect people’s health, safety, and basic rights. AI can be a powerful tool for improving care, efficiency, and access to information, but it needs strong, transparent oversight that includes clear accountability when things go wrong, protections against bias, and meaningful input from the communities it affects.

As a medical research scientist, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool to accelerate discovery, reduce diagnostic errors, and make healthcare more equitable—but only if it’s developed and deployed with rigorous evidence, transparency, and oversight similar to clinical trials. We need strong, enforceable regulations, independent auditing, and clear accountability to prevent harm, bias, and misuse, especially in high‑stakes domains like medicine and social services. My Jewish values and commitment to human dignity also mean AI systems must never replace human moral responsibility, but rather augment our capacity to care for and protect one another.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime creating art, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful new tool that can help us solve problems and even spark creativity, but it must never replace the value of human dignity, emotion, and judgment. I believe we need strong, democratically accountable rules—like clear transparency, protections against bias and job displacement, and strict limits on surveillance—to make sure AI serves people rather than profit alone.

As someone who designs technical components for a living and cares deeply about my family’s future, I see AI as a powerful tool that should enhance human capability, not replace human responsibility. It ought to be used to improve safety, efficiency, and quality of life—from smarter aircraft systems to better healthcare—while being governed by clear, enforceable rules that prevent abuse, protect privacy, and ensure accountability when things go wrong. I don’t think one group, whether government or big tech, should control the whole conversation; we need input from everyday citizens, engineers, ethicists, and faith communities to keep AI aligned with human dignity and freedom.

Artificial intelligence should be used to strengthen national security, improve government efficiency, and support American families and workers, but it must always stay under clear human control and reflect our core values. We need strict oversight, strong privacy protections, and serious consequences for abuse—especially by foreign adversaries or big tech companies that don’t share our interests. AI policies should be made by accountable elected officials, not unelected experts, and always respect individual rights, the dignity of work, and the sanctity of human life.

I think robots and smart computers should help people, like making doctors better and helping teachers so kids can learn more and still have fun. But big people should make strong rules so no one gets hurt or left out, and everyone is treated fair, because God wants us to care for each other and use our gifts in a good way.

I think artificial intelligence should be used carefully to help people—especially in areas like medicine, safety, and making everyday tasks easier—but not to replace human judgment, common sense, or good jobs. Our government, along with independent experts, should put strong rules in place so big companies can’t misuse it, protect our privacy, and make sure AI is guided by moral values and respect for human life, not just profit or politics.

Look, AI ought to be working for people, not the other way around—helping with healthcare, accessibility, and everyday tasks, especially for folks like me getting older and dealing with disabilities. But we can’t just trust big corporations to “do the right thing”; we need strong, enforceable regulations, public oversight, and strict rules on data privacy and bias so this stuff doesn’t deepen inequality or replace human judgment where compassion and accountability matter.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how small errors can hurt real people, I think AI should be used as a powerful assistant, not a replacement for human judgment, especially in areas like medicine, education, and public services. We need strict, enforceable regulations—like we have for drugs and medical devices—that require transparency, bias testing, data privacy protections, and clear lines of accountability when AI systems cause harm. AI development and deployment should be guided by public interest, not just corporate profit, with strong worker protections and community input so that the benefits are shared fairly and vulnerable groups aren’t left to shoulder the risks.

I think AI should be used to make everyday life smoother and fairer for people, like improving healthcare, public services, and education—not just to boost profits for big companies. But we need strong rules, like government oversight and clear accountability, to make sure it doesn’t take people’s jobs without a safety net, invade privacy, or build in bias against certain groups. AI should support workers, not replace them, and decisions that really affect people’s lives should always have a human being responsible at the end of the line.

Back in my day, we were taught that tools should serve people, not replace them, and I think artificial intelligence ought to be treated the same way—used to make work more efficient and accurate, but never to take away human responsibility, dignity, or jobs whenever that can be avoided. AI should be strictly governed with clear laws and strong oversight, especially around privacy, bias, and fraud, so it doesn’t harm workers, families, or our freedoms. I’d like to see regulations that hold companies accountable when AI is misused, while still allowing innovation that supports businesses, strengthens our economy, and upholds our traditional values.

As someone who works hands-on with telecom equipment and sees how much efficiency tech can bring, I think AI should be used to automate repetitive tasks, improve infrastructure reliability, and free people up to do higher-skill work, not to replace human judgment or responsibility. I’m wary of big government control, so I’d rather see AI risks managed through clear, limited regulations focused on safety, transparency, and liability, combined with industry standards and open auditing. Companies that build or deploy AI should be held accountable when their systems cause real harm, but we shouldn’t strangle innovation with blanket bans or overreach.

As someone who believes deeply in social justice and community, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should be used to expand access to education, healthcare, and opportunities—especially for those who are historically marginalized. But it must be governed with strong, enforceable regulations that prioritize transparency, accountability, and protections against bias and surveillance, shaped by input from everyday people, not just tech companies. AI should enhance human dignity and community well‑being, never replace human judgment or erode our freedoms.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday systems—like healthcare, schools, and government services—more efficient, fair, and accessible, especially for families and working people who don’t have time or money to waste. But its development and use must be tightly regulated by strong public laws, not just company promises, with transparency about how it works, protections against bias and surveillance, and clear accountability when it harms people.

As someone who works in a recording studio and sees how tech is reshaping creativity, I think AI should be used as a tool to expand human expression and make opportunities more accessible, not to replace people’s livelihoods or judgment. We need strong, enforceable regulations—like transparency requirements, bias audits, and labor protections—so that AI doesn’t deepen inequality or concentrate power in a few corporations. I’d like to see democratic oversight and public input guide how AI is deployed, with special attention to protecting privacy, mental health, and the rights of artists and workers.

I think robots and smart computers should help people be safe, happy, and have more time to play, like when grown‑ups use them to make cars safer or help doctors. But the big people need to watch them carefully, like keeping locks on the toy box, so they don’t hurt anyone or get out of control.

Artificial intelligence is a powerful tool, kind of like heavy equipment on a job site: it can help us build faster and safer, but only if it’s run by people who know what they’re doing and are held accountable. I think AI should be used to make work more efficient and improve things like healthcare and infrastructure, not to replace honest jobs or let big tech and government spy on folks. We need clear, common-sense regulations that protect privacy, prevent abuse, and keep decision-making in human hands, instead of turning everything over to some black-box algorithm.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I think artificial intelligence should serve people, not replace them, by taking over routine tasks so we can focus more on human relationships, critical thinking, and care for our communities and the environment. We need strong, transparent public oversight—through democratic institutions, not just tech companies—to make sure AI doesn’t deepen inequality, spread misinformation, or exploit students’ data.

As someone who works in tech and cares about both innovation and people, I think AI should be used to augment human capabilities, not replace them—especially in areas like healthcare, logistics, and accessibility where it can improve lives and reduce waste. But we need strong, enforceable regulations, like data privacy protections, algorithmic transparency, and bias audits, so that AI doesn’t deepen inequality or concentrate power in the hands of a few big companies. I’d like to see democratic oversight—public input, independent review boards, and clear accountability—so ordinary people, not just engineers or executives, help decide how AI shapes our future.
